trans-unit.source: Planning and Implementing Your Azure Rights Management Tenant Key
trans-unit.target: Planning and Implementing Your Azure Rights Management Tenant Key

trans-unit.source: Use the information in this topic to help you plan for and manage your Rights Management service (RMS) tenant key for Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: Use the information in this topic to help you plan for and manage your Rights Management service (RMS) tenant key for Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: For example, instead of Microsoft managing your tenant key (the default), you might want to manage your own tenant key to comply with specific regulations that apply to your organization.
trans-unit.target: For example, instead of Microsoft managing your tenant key (the default), you might want to manage your own tenant key to comply with specific regulations that apply to your organization.

trans-unit.source: Managing your own tenant key is also referred to as bring your own key, or BYOK.
trans-unit.target: Managing your own tenant key is also referred to as bring your own key, or BYOK.

trans-unit.source: The RMS tenant key is also known as the Server Licensor Certificate (SLC) key.
trans-unit.target: The RMS tenant key is also known as the Server Licensor Certificate (SLC) key.

trans-unit.source: Azure RMS maintains one or more keys for each organization that subscribes to Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: Azure RMS maintains one or more keys for each organization that subscribes to Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: Whenever a key is used for RMS within an organization (such as user keys, computer keys, document encryption keys), they cryptographically chain to your RMS tenant key.
trans-unit.target: Whenever a key is used for RMS within an organization (such as user keys, computer keys, document encryption keys), they cryptographically chain to your RMS tenant key.

trans-unit.source: At a glance: Use the following table as a quick guide to your recommended tenant key topology.
trans-unit.target: At a glance: Use the following table as a quick guide to your recommended tenant key topology.

trans-unit.source: Then, use the additional sections for more information.
trans-unit.target: Then, use the additional sections for more information.

trans-unit.source: If you deploy Azure RMS by using a tenant key that is managed by Microsoft, you can change to BYOK later.
trans-unit.target: If you deploy Azure RMS by using a tenant key that is managed by Microsoft, you can change to BYOK later.

trans-unit.source: However, you cannot currently change your Azure RMS tenant key from BYOK to managed by Microsoft.
trans-unit.target: However, you cannot currently change your Azure RMS tenant key from BYOK to managed by Microsoft.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Choose your tenant key topology: Managed by Microsoft (the default) or managed by you (BYOK)
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Choose your tenant key topology: Managed by Microsoft (the default) or managed by you (BYOK)

trans-unit.source: Decide which tenant key topology is best for your organization.
trans-unit.target: Decide which tenant key topology is best for your organization.

trans-unit.source: By default, Azure RMS generates your tenant key and manages most aspects of the tenant key lifecycle.
trans-unit.target: By default, Azure RMS generates your tenant key and manages most aspects of the tenant key lifecycle.

trans-unit.source: This is the simplest option with the lowest administrative overheads.
trans-unit.target: This is the simplest option with the lowest administrative overheads.

trans-unit.source: In most cases, you do not even need to know that you have a tenant key.
trans-unit.target: In most cases, you do not even need to know that you have a tenant key.

trans-unit.source: You just sign up for Azure RMS and the rest of the key management process is handled by Microsoft.
trans-unit.target: You just sign up for Azure RMS and the rest of the key management process is handled by Microsoft.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you might want complete control over your tenant key, which involves creating your tenant key and keeping the master copy on your premises.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you might want complete control over your tenant key, which involves creating your tenant key and keeping the master copy on your premises.

trans-unit.source: This scenario is often referred to as bring your own key (BYOK).
trans-unit.target: This scenario is often referred to as bring your own key (BYOK).

trans-unit.source: With this option, the following happens:
trans-unit.target: With this option, the following happens:

trans-unit.source: You generate your tenant key on your premises, in line with your IT policies.
trans-unit.target: You generate your tenant key on your premises, in line with your IT policies.

trans-unit.source: You securely transfer the tenant key from a Hardware Security Module (HSM) in your possession to HSMs that are owned and managed by Microsoft.
trans-unit.target: You securely transfer the tenant key from a Hardware Security Module (HSM) in your possession to HSMs that are owned and managed by Microsoft.

trans-unit.source: Throughout this process, your tenant key never leaves the hardware protection boundary.
trans-unit.target: Throughout this process, your tenant key never leaves the hardware protection boundary.

trans-unit.source: When you transfer your tenant key to Microsoft, it stays protected by Thales HSMs.
trans-unit.target: When you transfer your tenant key to Microsoft, it stays protected by Thales HSMs.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft has worked with Thales to ensure that your tenant key cannot be extracted from Microsoft’s HSMs.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft has worked with Thales to ensure that your tenant key cannot be extracted from Microsoft’s HSMs.

trans-unit.source: Although it’s optional, you will also probably want to use the near real-time usage logs from Azure RMS to see exactly how and when your tenant key is being used.
trans-unit.target: Although it’s optional, you will also probably want to use the near real-time usage logs from Azure RMS to see exactly how and when your tenant key is being used.

trans-unit.source: As an additional protection measure, Azure RMS uses separate security worlds for its data centers in North America, EMEA (Europe, Middle East and Africa), and Asia.
trans-unit.target: As an additional protection measure, Azure RMS uses separate security worlds for its data centers in North America, EMEA (Europe, Middle East and Africa), and Asia.

trans-unit.source: When you manage your own tenant key, it is tied to the security world of the region in which your RMS tenant is registered.
trans-unit.target: When you manage your own tenant key, it is tied to the security world of the region in which your RMS tenant is registered.

trans-unit.source: For example, a tenant key from a European customer cannot be used in data centers in North America or Asia.
trans-unit.target: For example, a tenant key from a European customer cannot be used in data centers in North America or Asia.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>The tenant key lifecycle
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>The tenant key lifecycle

trans-unit.source: If you decide that Microsoft should manage your tenant key, Microsoft handles most of the key lifecycle operations.
trans-unit.target: If you decide that Microsoft should manage your tenant key, Microsoft handles most of the key lifecycle operations.

trans-unit.source: However, if you decide to manage your tenant key, you are responsible for many of the key lifecycle operations and some additional procedures.
trans-unit.target: However, if you decide to manage your tenant key, you are responsible for many of the key lifecycle operations and some additional procedures.

trans-unit.source: The following diagrams show and compares these two options.
trans-unit.target: The following diagrams show and compares these two options.

trans-unit.source: The first diagram shows how little administrator overheads there are for you in the default configuration when Microsoft manages the tenant key.
trans-unit.target: The first diagram shows how little administrator overheads there are for you in the default configuration when Microsoft manages the tenant key.

trans-unit.source: The second diagram shows the additional steps required when you manage your own tenant key.
trans-unit.target: The second diagram shows the additional steps required when you manage your own tenant key.

trans-unit.source: If you decide to let Microsoft manage your tenant key, no further action is required for you to generate the key and you can skip the following sections and go straight to <link><linkText>Next steps</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you decide to let Microsoft manage your tenant key, no further action is required for you to generate the key and you can skip the following sections and go straight to <link><linkText>Next steps</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If you decide to manage your tenant key yourself, read the following sections for more information.
trans-unit.target: If you decide to manage your tenant key yourself, read the following sections for more information.

trans-unit.source: More information about Thales HSMs and Microsoft additions
trans-unit.target: More information about Thales HSMs and Microsoft additions

trans-unit.source: Azure RMS uses Thales HSMs to protect your keys.
trans-unit.target: Azure RMS uses Thales HSMs to protect your keys.

trans-unit.source: Thales e-Security is a leading global provider of data encryption and cyber security solutions to the financial services, high technology, manufacturing, government, and technology sectors.
trans-unit.target: Thales e-Security is a leading global provider of data encryption and cyber security solutions to the financial services, high technology, manufacturing, government, and technology sectors.

trans-unit.source: With a 40-year track record of protecting corporate and government information, Thales solutions are used by four of the five largest energy and aerospace companies, 22 NATO countries, and secure more than 80 per cent of worldwide payment transactions.
trans-unit.target: With a 40-year track record of protecting corporate and government information, Thales solutions are used by four of the five largest energy and aerospace companies, 22 NATO countries, and secure more than 80 per cent of worldwide payment transactions.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft has collaborated with Thales to enhance the state of art for HSMs.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft has collaborated with Thales to enhance the state of art for HSMs.

trans-unit.source: These enhancements enable you to get the typical benefits of hosted services without relinquishing control over your keys.
trans-unit.target: These enhancements enable you to get the typical benefits of hosted services without relinquishing control over your keys.

trans-unit.source: Specifically, these enhancements let Microsoft manage the HSMs so that you do not have to.
trans-unit.target: Specifically, these enhancements let Microsoft manage the HSMs so that you do not have to.

trans-unit.source: As a cloud service, Azure RMS scales up at short notice to meet your organization’s usage spikes.
trans-unit.target: As a cloud service, Azure RMS scales up at short notice to meet your organization’s usage spikes.

trans-unit.source: At the same time, your key is protected inside Microsoft’s HSMs: You retain control over the key lifecycle because you generate the key and transfer it to Microsoft’s HSMs.
trans-unit.target: At the same time, your key is protected inside Microsoft’s HSMs: You retain control over the key lifecycle because you generate the key and transfer it to Microsoft’s HSMs.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Thales HSMs and Azure RMS</linkText><title></title></link> on the Thales web site.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Thales HSMs and Azure RMS</linkText><title></title></link> on the Thales web site.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>BYOK pricing and restrictions
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>BYOK pricing and restrictions

trans-unit.source: Organization that have an IT-managed Azure subscription can use BYOK and log its usage at no extra charge.
trans-unit.target: Organization that have an IT-managed Azure subscription can use BYOK and log its usage at no extra charge.

trans-unit.source: Organizations that use RMS for individuals cannot use BYOK and logging because they do not have a tenant administrator to configure these features.
trans-unit.target: Organizations that use RMS for individuals cannot use BYOK and logging because they do not have a tenant administrator to configure these features.

trans-unit.source: For more information about RMS for individuals, see <link><linkText>RMS for Individuals and Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about RMS for individuals, see <link><linkText>RMS for Individuals and Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: BYOK and logging work seamlessly with every application that integrates with Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: BYOK and logging work seamlessly with every application that integrates with Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: This includes cloud services such as SharePoint Online, on-premises servers that run Exchange and SharePoint that work with Azure RMS by using the RMS connector, and client applications such as Office 2013.
trans-unit.target: This includes cloud services such as SharePoint Online, on-premises servers that run Exchange and SharePoint that work with Azure RMS by using the RMS connector, and client applications such as Office 2013.

trans-unit.source: You will get key usage logs regardless of which application makes requests of Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: You will get key usage logs regardless of which application makes requests of Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: There is one exception: Currently, Azure RMS BYOK is not compatible with Exchange Online.
trans-unit.target: There is one exception: Currently, Azure RMS BYOK is not compatible with Exchange Online.

trans-unit.source: If you want to use Exchange Online, we recommend that you deploy Azure RMS in the default key management mode now, where Microsoft generates and manages your key.
trans-unit.target: If you want to use Exchange Online, we recommend that you deploy Azure RMS in the default key management mode now, where Microsoft generates and manages your key.

trans-unit.source: You have the option to move to BYOK later, for example, when Exchange Online does support Azure RMS BYOK.
trans-unit.target: You have the option to move to BYOK later, for example, when Exchange Online does support Azure RMS BYOK.

trans-unit.source: However, if you cannot wait, another option is to deploy Azure RMS with BYOK now, with reduced RMS functionality for Exchange Online (unprotected emails and unprotected attachments remain fully functional):
trans-unit.target: However, if you cannot wait, another option is to deploy Azure RMS with BYOK now, with reduced RMS functionality for Exchange Online (unprotected emails and unprotected attachments remain fully functional):

trans-unit.source: Protected emails or protected attachments in Outlook Web Access cannot be displayed.
trans-unit.target: Protected emails or protected attachments in Outlook Web Access cannot be displayed.

trans-unit.source: Protected emails on mobile devices that use Exchange ActiveSync IRM cannot be displayed.
trans-unit.target: Protected emails on mobile devices that use Exchange ActiveSync IRM cannot be displayed.

trans-unit.source: Transport decryption (for example, to scan for malware) and journal decryption is not possible, so protected emails and protected attachments will be skipped.
trans-unit.target: Transport decryption (for example, to scan for malware) and journal decryption is not possible, so protected emails and protected attachments will be skipped.

trans-unit.source: Transport protection rules and data loss prevention (DLP) that enforce IRM policies is not possible, so RMS protection cannot be applied by using these methods.
trans-unit.target: Transport protection rules and data loss prevention (DLP) that enforce IRM policies is not possible, so RMS protection cannot be applied by using these methods.

trans-unit.source: Server-based search for protected emails, so protected emails will be skipped.
trans-unit.target: Server-based search for protected emails, so protected emails will be skipped.

trans-unit.source: When you use Azure RMS BYOK with reduced RMS functionality for Exchange Online, RMS will work with email clients in Outlook on Windows and Mac, and on other email clients that don't use Exchange ActiveSync IRM.
trans-unit.target: When you use Azure RMS BYOK with reduced RMS functionality for Exchange Online, RMS will work with email clients in Outlook on Windows and Mac, and on other email clients that don't use Exchange ActiveSync IRM.

trans-unit.source: If you are migrating to Azure RMS from AD RMS, you might have imported your key as a trusted publishing domain (TPD) to Exchange Online (also called BYOK in Exchange terminology, which is separate from Azure RMS BYOK).
trans-unit.target: If you are migrating to Azure RMS from AD RMS, you might have imported your key as a trusted publishing domain (TPD) to Exchange Online (also called BYOK in Exchange terminology, which is separate from Azure RMS BYOK).

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, you must remove the TPD from Exchange Online to avoid conflicting templates and policies.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, you must remove the TPD from Exchange Online to avoid conflicting templates and policies.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Remove-RMSTrustedPublishingDomain</linkText><title></title></link> from the Exchange Online cmdlets library.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Remove-RMSTrustedPublishingDomain</linkText><title></title></link> from the Exchange Online cmdlets library.

trans-unit.source: Sometimes, the Azure RMS BYOK exception for Exchange Online is not a problem in practice.
trans-unit.target: Sometimes, the Azure RMS BYOK exception for Exchange Online is not a problem in practice.

trans-unit.source: For example, organizations that need BYOK and logging run their data applications (Exchange, SharePoint, Office) on-premises, and use Azure RMS for functionality that is not easily available with on-premises AD RMS (for example, collaboration with other companies and access from mobile clients).
trans-unit.target: For example, organizations that need BYOK and logging run their data applications (Exchange, SharePoint, Office) on-premises, and use Azure RMS for functionality that is not easily available with on-premises AD RMS (for example, collaboration with other companies and access from mobile clients).

trans-unit.source: Both BYOK and logging work well in this scenario and allow the organization to have full control over their Azure RMS subscription.
trans-unit.target: Both BYOK and logging work well in this scenario and allow the organization to have full control over their Azure RMS subscription.

trans-unit.target: If you have already started to use <token href="../Token/aad_rightsmanagement_1_md.md"/> (the service is activated) and you have users who run Office 2010, contact Microsoft Customer Support Services (CSS) before you run these procedures.

trans-unit.target: Depending on your scenario and requirements, you can still use BYOK but with some limitations or additional steps.

trans-unit.source: Also contact CSS if your organization has specific policies for handling keys.
trans-unit.target: Also contact CSS if your organization has specific policies for handling keys.

trans-unit.target: See the following table for a list of prerequisites for bring your own key (BYOK).

trans-unit.target: For more information about the available subscriptions, see the <link><linkText>Cloud subscriptions that support Azure RMS</linkText><title></title></link> section in the <link><linkText>Requirements for Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link> topic.

trans-unit.source: You do not use RMS for individuals or Exchange Online.
trans-unit.target: You do not use RMS for individuals or Exchange Online.

trans-unit.source: Or, if you use Exchange Online, you understand and accept the limitations of using BYOK with this configuration.
trans-unit.target: Or, if you use Exchange Online, you understand and accept the limitations of using BYOK with this configuration.

trans-unit.target: For more information about the restrictions and current limitations for BYOK, see the BYOK pricing and restrictions section in this topic.Important: Currently, BYOK is not compatible with Exchange Online.

trans-unit.source: Thales HSM, smartcards, and support software.Note: If you are migrating from AD RMS to Azure RMS by using software key to hardware key, you must have a minimum version of 11.62 for the Thales drivers.
trans-unit.target: Thales HSM, smartcards, and support software.Note: If you are migrating from AD RMS to Azure RMS by using software key to hardware key, you must have a minimum version of 11.62 for the Thales drivers.

trans-unit.source: You must have access to a Thales Hardware Security Module and basic operational knowledge of Thales HSMs.
trans-unit.target: You must have access to a Thales Hardware Security Module and basic operational knowledge of Thales HSMs.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Thales Hardware Security Module</linkText><title></title></link> for the list of compatible models, or to purchase an HSM if you do not have one.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Thales Hardware Security Module</linkText><title></title></link> for the list of compatible models, or to purchase an HSM if you do not have one.

trans-unit.source: If you want to transfer your tenant key over the Internet rather than physically be present in Redmond, USA.
trans-unit.target: If you want to transfer your tenant key over the Internet rather than physically be present in Redmond, USA.

trans-unit.source: there are 3 requirements:<html></html><html></html>Requirement 1: An offline x64 workstation with a minimum Windows operation system of Windows 7 and Thales nShield software that is at least version 11.62.<html></html><html></html>If this workstation runs Windows 7, you must <link><linkText>install Microsoft .NET Framework 4.5</linkText><title></title></link>.<html></html><html></html>Requirement 2: A workstation that is connected to the Internet and has a minimum Windows operation system of Windows 7.<html></html><html></html>Requirement 2: A USB drive or other portable storage device that has at least 16 MB free space.
trans-unit.target: there are 3 requirements:<html></html><html></html>Requirement 1: An offline x64 workstation with a minimum Windows operation system of Windows 7 and Thales nShield software that is at least version 11.62.<html></html><html></html>If this workstation runs Windows 7, you must <link><linkText>install Microsoft .NET Framework 4.5</linkText><title></title></link>.<html></html><html></html>Requirement 2: A workstation that is connected to the Internet and has a minimum Windows operation system of Windows 7.<html></html><html></html>Requirement 2: A USB drive or other portable storage device that has at least 16 MB free space.

trans-unit.source: These prerequisites are not required if you travel to Redmond and transfer your tenant key in person.<html></html><html></html>For security reasons, we recommend that the first workstation is not connected to a network.
trans-unit.target: These prerequisites are not required if you travel to Redmond and transfer your tenant key in person.<html></html><html></html>For security reasons, we recommend that the first workstation is not connected to a network.

trans-unit.source: However, this is not programmatically enforced.Note: In the instructions that follow, this first workstation is referred to as the disconnected workstation.In addition, if your tenant key is for a production network, we recommend that you use a second, separate workstation to download the toolset and upload the tenant key.
trans-unit.target: However, this is not programmatically enforced.Note: In the instructions that follow, this first workstation is referred to as the disconnected workstation.In addition, if your tenant key is for a production network, we recommend that you use a second, separate workstation to download the toolset and upload the tenant key.

trans-unit.source: But for testing purposes, you can use the same workstation as the first one.Note: In the instructions that follow, this second workstation is referred to as the Internet-connected workstation.
trans-unit.target: But for testing purposes, you can use the same workstation as the first one.Note: In the instructions that follow, this second workstation is referred to as the Internet-connected workstation.

trans-unit.source: Optional: Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: Optional: Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: If you want to log your tenant key usage (and Rights Management usage), you must have a subscription to Azure and sufficient storage on Azure to store your logs.
trans-unit.target: If you want to log your tenant key usage (and Rights Management usage), you must have a subscription to Azure and sufficient storage on Azure to store your logs.

trans-unit.source: The procedures to generate and use your own tenant key depend on whether you want to do this over the Internet or in person:
trans-unit.target: The procedures to generate and use your own tenant key depend on whether you want to do this over the Internet or in person:

trans-unit.source: Over the Internet: This requires some extra configuration steps, such as downloading and using a toolset and Windows PowerShell cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: Over the Internet: This requires some extra configuration steps, such as downloading and using a toolset and Windows PowerShell cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: However, you do not have to physically be in a Microsoft facility to transfer your tenant key.
trans-unit.target: However, you do not have to physically be in a Microsoft facility to transfer your tenant key.

trans-unit.source: Security is maintained by the following methods:
trans-unit.target: Security is maintained by the following methods:

trans-unit.source: You generate the tenant key from an offline workstation, which reduces the attack surface.
trans-unit.target: You generate the tenant key from an offline workstation, which reduces the attack surface.

trans-unit.source: The tenant key is encrypted with a Key Exchange Key (KEK), which stays encrypted until it is transferred to the Azure RMS HSMs.
trans-unit.target: The tenant key is encrypted with a Key Exchange Key (KEK), which stays encrypted until it is transferred to the Azure RMS HSMs.

trans-unit.source: Only the encrypted version of your tenant key leaves the original workstation.
trans-unit.target: Only the encrypted version of your tenant key leaves the original workstation.

trans-unit.source: A tool sets properties on your tenant key that binds your tenant key to the Azure RMS security world.
trans-unit.target: A tool sets properties on your tenant key that binds your tenant key to the Azure RMS security world.

trans-unit.source: So after the Azure RMS HSMs receive and decrypt your tenant key, only these HSMs can use it.
trans-unit.target: So after the Azure RMS HSMs receive and decrypt your tenant key, only these HSMs can use it.

trans-unit.source: Your tenant key cannot be exported.
trans-unit.target: Your tenant key cannot be exported.

trans-unit.source: This binding is enforced by the Thales HSMs.
trans-unit.target: This binding is enforced by the Thales HSMs.

trans-unit.source: The Key Exchange Key (KEK) that is used to encrypt your tenant key is generated inside the Azure RMS HSMs and is not exportable.
trans-unit.target: The Key Exchange Key (KEK) that is used to encrypt your tenant key is generated inside the Azure RMS HSMs and is not exportable.

trans-unit.source: The HSMs enforce that there can be no clear version of the KEK outside the HSMs.
trans-unit.target: The HSMs enforce that there can be no clear version of the KEK outside the HSMs.

trans-unit.source: In addition, the toolset includes attestation from Thales that the KEK is not exportable and was generated inside a genuine HSM that was manufactured by Thales.
trans-unit.target: In addition, the toolset includes attestation from Thales that the KEK is not exportable and was generated inside a genuine HSM that was manufactured by Thales.

trans-unit.source: The toolset includes attestation from Thales that the Azure RMS security world was also generated on a genuine HSM manufactured by Thales.
trans-unit.target: The toolset includes attestation from Thales that the Azure RMS security world was also generated on a genuine HSM manufactured by Thales.

trans-unit.source: This proves to you that Microsoft is using genuine hardware.
trans-unit.target: This proves to you that Microsoft is using genuine hardware.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft uses separate KEKs as well as separate Security Worlds in each geographical region, which ensures that your tenant key can be used only in data centers in the region in which you encrypted it.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft uses separate KEKs as well as separate Security Worlds in each geographical region, which ensures that your tenant key can be used only in data centers in the region in which you encrypted it.

trans-unit.source: For example, a tenant key from a European customer cannot be used in data centers in North American or Asia.
trans-unit.target: For example, a tenant key from a European customer cannot be used in data centers in North American or Asia.

trans-unit.source: Your tenant key can safely move through untrusted computers and networks because it is encrypted and secured with access control level permissions, which makes it usable only within your HSMs and Microsoft’s HSMs for Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: Your tenant key can safely move through untrusted computers and networks because it is encrypted and secured with access control level permissions, which makes it usable only within your HSMs and Microsoft’s HSMs for Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: You can use the scripts that are provided in the toolset to verify the security measures and read more information about how this works from Thales: <link><linkText>Hardware Key management in the RMS Cloud</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can use the scripts that are provided in the toolset to verify the security measures and read more information about how this works from Thales: <link><linkText>Hardware Key management in the RMS Cloud</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In person: This requires that you contact Microsoft Customer Support Services (CSS) to schedule a key transfer appointment for Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: In person: This requires that you contact Microsoft Customer Support Services (CSS) to schedule a key transfer appointment for Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: You must travel to a Microsoft office in Redmond, Washington, United States of America to transfer your tenant key to the Azure RMS security world.
trans-unit.target: You must travel to a Microsoft office in Redmond, Washington, United States of America to transfer your tenant key to the Azure RMS security world.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 1: Install Windows PowerShell for Azure Rights Management
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 1: Install Windows PowerShell for Azure Rights Management

trans-unit.source: From the Internet-connected workstation, download and install the Windows PowerShell module for Azure Rights Management.
trans-unit.target: From the Internet-connected workstation, download and install the Windows PowerShell module for Azure Rights Management.

trans-unit.source: If you have previously downloaded this Windows PowerShell module, run the following command to check that your version number is at least 2.1.0.0: (Get-Module aadrm -ListAvailable).Version
trans-unit.target: If you have previously downloaded this Windows PowerShell module, run the following command to check that your version number is at least 2.1.0.0: (Get-Module aadrm -ListAvailable).Version

trans-unit.source: For installation instructions, see <link><linkText>Installing Windows PowerShell for Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For installation instructions, see <link><linkText>Installing Windows PowerShell for Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 2: Get your Azure Active Directory tenant ID
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 2: Get your Azure Active Directory tenant ID

trans-unit.source: Start Windows PowerShell with the Run as administrator option, and then run the following commands:
trans-unit.target: Start Windows PowerShell with the Run as administrator option, and then run the following commands:

trans-unit.source: Use the <link><linkText>Connect-AadrmService</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet to connect to the Azure RMS service:
trans-unit.target: Use the <link><linkText>Connect-AadrmService</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet to connect to the Azure RMS service:

trans-unit.source: When prompted, enter your <token href="../Token/aad_rightsmanagement_1_md.md"/> tenant administrator credentials (typically, you will use an account that is a global administrator for Azure Active Directory or Office 365).
trans-unit.target: When prompted, enter your <token href="../Token/aad_rightsmanagement_1_md.md"/> tenant administrator credentials (typically, you will use an account that is a global administrator for Azure Active Directory or Office 365).

trans-unit.source: Use the <link><linkText>Get-AadrmConfiguration</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet to display the configuration of your tenant:
trans-unit.target: Use the <link><linkText>Get-AadrmConfiguration</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet to display the configuration of your tenant:

trans-unit.source: From the output, save the GUID from the first line (BPOSId).
trans-unit.target: From the output, save the GUID from the first line (BPOSId).

trans-unit.source: This is your Azure Active Directory tenant ID, which you will need later when you prepare your tenant key for upload.
trans-unit.target: This is your Azure Active Directory tenant ID, which you will need later when you prepare your tenant key for upload.

trans-unit.source: Use the <link><linkText>Disconnect-AadrmService</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet to disconnect from the Azure RMS service until you are ready to upload your key:
trans-unit.target: Use the <link><linkText>Disconnect-AadrmService</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet to disconnect from the Azure RMS service until you are ready to upload your key:

trans-unit.source: Do not close the Windows PowerShell window.
trans-unit.target: Do not close the Windows PowerShell window.

trans-unit.target: On the disconnected workstation, following these 3 steps to generate your own tenant key:

trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Step 1: Create a security world</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 1: Create a security world
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 1: Create a security world

trans-unit.source: Start a command prompt and run the Thales new-world program.
trans-unit.target: Start a command prompt and run the Thales new-world program.

trans-unit.source: This program creates a Security World file at %NFAST_KMDATA%\local\world, which corresponds to the C:\ProgramData\nCipher\Key Management Data\local folder.
trans-unit.target: This program creates a Security World file at %NFAST_KMDATA%\local\world, which corresponds to the C:\ProgramData\nCipher\Key Management Data\local folder.

trans-unit.source: You can use different values for the quorum but in our example, you’re prompted to enter three blank cards and pins for each one.
trans-unit.target: You can use different values for the quorum but in our example, you’re prompted to enter three blank cards and pins for each one.

trans-unit.source: Then, any two cards will be required to have administrative access to the security world (your specified quorum).
trans-unit.target: Then, any two cards will be required to have administrative access to the security world (your specified quorum).

trans-unit.source: These cards become the Administrator Card Set for the new security world.
trans-unit.target: These cards become the Administrator Card Set for the new security world.

trans-unit.source: At this stage, you can specify the password or PIN for each ACS card, or add it later with a command.
trans-unit.target: At this stage, you can specify the password or PIN for each ACS card, or add it later with a command.

trans-unit.source: You can verify the current configuration status of your HSM by using the nkminfo command.
trans-unit.target: You can verify the current configuration status of your HSM by using the nkminfo command.

trans-unit.source: Then do the following:
trans-unit.target: Then do the following:

trans-unit.source: Install the Thales CNG provider as described in the Thales documentation, and configure it to use the new security world.
trans-unit.target: Install the Thales CNG provider as described in the Thales documentation, and configure it to use the new security world.

trans-unit.source: Back up the world file in %nfast_kmdata%\local.
trans-unit.target: Back up the world file in %nfast_kmdata%\local.

trans-unit.source: Secure and protect the world file, the Administrator Cards, and their pins, and make sure that no single person has access to more than one card.
trans-unit.target: Secure and protect the world file, the Administrator Cards, and their pins, and make sure that no single person has access to more than one card.

trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 2: Validate the downloaded package

trans-unit.target: This step is optional but recommended so that you can validate the following:

trans-unit.target: The Key Exchange Key that is included in the toolset has been generated from a genuine Thales HSM.

trans-unit.target: The hash of the Azure RMS Security World that is included in the toolset has been generated in a genuine Thales HSM.

trans-unit.source: The Key Exchange Key is non-exportable.
trans-unit.target: The Key Exchange Key is non-exportable.

trans-unit.source: To validate the downloaded package, the HSM must be connected, powered on, and must have a security world on it (such as the one you’ve just created).
trans-unit.target: To validate the downloaded package, the HSM must be connected, powered on, and must have a security world on it (such as the one you’ve just created).

trans-unit.target: To validate the downloaded package

trans-unit.target: Run the verifykeypackage.py script by tying one of the following, depending on your region:

trans-unit.target: For North America:

trans-unit.target: For Europe:

trans-unit.target: For Asia:

trans-unit.source: The Thales software includes a Python interpreter at %NFAST_HOME%\python\bin
trans-unit.target: The Thales software includes a Python interpreter at %NFAST_HOME%\python\bin

trans-unit.source: Confirm that you see the following, which indicates successful validation: Result: SUCCESS
trans-unit.target: Confirm that you see the following, which indicates successful validation: Result: SUCCESS

trans-unit.source: This script validates the signer chain up to the Thales root key.
trans-unit.target: This script validates the signer chain up to the Thales root key.

trans-unit.source: The hash of this root key is embedded in the script and its value should be 59178a47 de508c3f 291277ee 184f46c4 f1d9c639.
trans-unit.target: The hash of this root key is embedded in the script and its value should be 59178a47 de508c3f 291277ee 184f46c4 f1d9c639.

trans-unit.source: You can also confirm this value separately by visiting the <link><linkText>Thales website</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can also confirm this value separately by visiting the <link><linkText>Thales website</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You’re now ready to create a new key that will be your RMS tenant key.
trans-unit.target: You’re now ready to create a new key that will be your RMS tenant key.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 3: Create a new key
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 3: Create a new key

trans-unit.source: Generate a CNG key by using the Thales generatekey and cngimport programs.
trans-unit.target: Generate a CNG key by using the Thales generatekey and cngimport programs.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command to generate the key:
trans-unit.target: Run the following command to generate the key:

trans-unit.source: When you run this command, use these instructions:
trans-unit.target: When you run this command, use these instructions:

trans-unit.source: For the key size, we recommend 2048 but also support 1024-bit RSA keys for existing AD RMS customers who have such keys and are migrating to Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: For the key size, we recommend 2048 but also support 1024-bit RSA keys for existing AD RMS customers who have such keys and are migrating to Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: Replace the value of contosokey for the ident and plainname with any string value.
trans-unit.target: Replace the value of contosokey for the ident and plainname with any string value.

trans-unit.source: To minimize administrative overheads and reduce the risk of errors, we recommend that you use the same value for both, and use all lower case characters.
trans-unit.target: To minimize administrative overheads and reduce the risk of errors, we recommend that you use the same value for both, and use all lower case characters.

trans-unit.source: The pubexp is left blank (default) in this example, but you can specify specific values.
trans-unit.target: The pubexp is left blank (default) in this example, but you can specify specific values.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the Thales documentation.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the Thales documentation.

trans-unit.source: Then run the following command to import the key to CNG:
trans-unit.target: Then run the following command to import the key to CNG:

trans-unit.source: When you run this command, use these instructions:
trans-unit.target: When you run this command, use these instructions:

trans-unit.source: Replace contosokey with the same value that you specified in Step 1: Create a security world from the Generate your tenant key section.
trans-unit.target: Replace contosokey with the same value that you specified in Step 1: Create a security world from the Generate your tenant key section.

trans-unit.source: Use the -M option so that the key is suitable for this scenario.
trans-unit.target: Use the -M option so that the key is suitable for this scenario.

trans-unit.source: Without this, the resultant key will be a user-specific key for the current user.
trans-unit.target: Without this, the resultant key will be a user-specific key for the current user.

trans-unit.source: This command creates a Tokenized Key file in your %NFAST_KMDATA%\local folder with a name starting with key_caping_ followed by a SID.
trans-unit.target: This command creates a Tokenized Key file in your %NFAST_KMDATA%\local folder with a name starting with key_caping_ followed by a SID.

trans-unit.source: For example: key_caping_machine--801c1a878c925fd9df4d62ba001b94701c039e2fb.
trans-unit.target: For example: key_caping_machine--801c1a878c925fd9df4d62ba001b94701c039e2fb.

trans-unit.source: This file contains an encrypted key.
trans-unit.target: This file contains an encrypted key.

trans-unit.source: You can see the current configuration status of your keys by using the nkminfo –k command.
trans-unit.target: You can see the current configuration status of your keys by using the nkminfo –k command.

trans-unit.source: Back up this Tokenized Key File in a safe location.
trans-unit.target: Back up this Tokenized Key File in a safe location.

trans-unit.source: When you later transfer your key to Azure RMS, Microsoft cannot export this key back to you so it becomes extremely important that you back up your key and security world safely.
trans-unit.target: When you later transfer your key to Azure RMS, Microsoft cannot export this key back to you so it becomes extremely important that you back up your key and security world safely.

trans-unit.source: Contact Thales for guidance and best practices for backing up your key.
trans-unit.target: Contact Thales for guidance and best practices for backing up your key.

trans-unit.source: You are now ready to transfer your tenant key to Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: You are now ready to transfer your tenant key to Azure RMS.

trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 1: Connect to Azure RMS

trans-unit.source: Return to the Windows PowerShell window and type the following:
trans-unit.target: Return to the Windows PowerShell window and type the following:

trans-unit.source: Reconnect to the <token href="../Token/aad_rightsmanagement_1_md.md"/> service:
trans-unit.target: Reconnect to the <token href="../Token/aad_rightsmanagement_1_md.md"/> service:

trans-unit.source: You are prompted to confirm this action.
trans-unit.target: You are prompted to confirm this action.

trans-unit.source: It’s important to understand that this action cannot be undone.
trans-unit.target: It’s important to understand that this action cannot be undone.

trans-unit.source: When you upload a tenant key, it automatically becomes your organization’s primary tenant key and users will start to use this tenant key when they protect documents and files.
trans-unit.target: When you upload a tenant key, it automatically becomes your organization’s primary tenant key and users will start to use this tenant key when they protect documents and files.

trans-unit.source: If the upload is successful, you will see the following message: The Rights management service successfully added the key.
trans-unit.target: If the upload is successful, you will see the following message: The Rights management service successfully added the key.

trans-unit.source: Expect a replication delay for the change to propagate to all <token href="../Token/aad_rightsmanagement_1_md.md"/> data centers.
trans-unit.target: Expect a replication delay for the change to propagate to all <token href="../Token/aad_rightsmanagement_1_md.md"/> data centers.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 3: Enumerate your tenant keys – as needed
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 3: Enumerate your tenant keys – as needed

trans-unit.source: Use the Get-AadrmKeys cmdlet again to see the change in your tenant key, and whenever you want to see a list of your tenant keys.
trans-unit.target: Use the Get-AadrmKeys cmdlet again to see the change in your tenant key, and whenever you want to see a list of your tenant keys.

trans-unit.source: The tenant keys displayed include the initial tenant key that Microsoft generated for you, and any tenant keys that you added:
trans-unit.target: The tenant keys displayed include the initial tenant key that Microsoft generated for you, and any tenant keys that you added:

trans-unit.source: new-world.exe --initialize --cipher-suite=DLf1024s160mRijndael --module=1 --acs-quorum=2/3
trans-unit.target: new-world.exe --initialize --cipher-suite=DLf1024s160mRijndael --module=1 --acs-quorum=2/3

trans-unit.source: generatekey --generate simple type=RSA size=2048 protect=module ident=contosokey plainname=contosokey nvram=no pubexp=
trans-unit.target: generatekey --generate simple type=RSA size=2048 protect=module ident=contosokey plainname=contosokey nvram=no pubexp=

trans-unit.source: cngimport --import –M --key=contosokey --appname=simple contosokey
trans-unit.target: cngimport --import –M --key=contosokey --appname=simple contosokey

trans-unit.source: When you run this command, use these instructions:
trans-unit.target: When you run this command, use these instructions:

trans-unit.source: Replace contosokey with the same value that you specified in Step 1.
trans-unit.target: Replace contosokey with the same value that you specified in Step 1.

trans-unit.source: Use the -M option so that the key is suitable for this scenario.
trans-unit.target: Use the -M option so that the key is suitable for this scenario.

trans-unit.source: Without this, the resultant key will be a user-specific key for the current user.
trans-unit.target: Without this, the resultant key will be a user-specific key for the current user.

trans-unit.source: This command creates a Tokenized Key file in your %NFAST_KMDATA%\local folder with a name starting with key_caping_ followed by a SID.
trans-unit.target: This command creates a Tokenized Key file in your %NFAST_KMDATA%\local folder with a name starting with key_caping_ followed by a SID.

trans-unit.source: For example: key_caping_machine--801c1a878c925fd9df4d62ba001b94701c039e2fb.
trans-unit.target: For example: key_caping_machine--801c1a878c925fd9df4d62ba001b94701c039e2fb.

trans-unit.source: This file contains an encrypted key.
trans-unit.target: This file contains an encrypted key.

trans-unit.source: Back up this Tokenized Key File in a safe location.
trans-unit.target: Back up this Tokenized Key File in a safe location.

trans-unit.source: When you later transfer your key to Azure RMS, Microsoft will have a non-recoverable copy of your key.
trans-unit.target: When you later transfer your key to Azure RMS, Microsoft will have a non-recoverable copy of your key.

trans-unit.source: This means that nobody can retrieve your key from the HSMs at Microsoft.
trans-unit.target: This means that nobody can retrieve your key from the HSMs at Microsoft.

trans-unit.source: This allows you to retain exclusive control over your tenant key.
trans-unit.target: This allows you to retain exclusive control over your tenant key.

trans-unit.source: Therefore it becomes extremely important that you back up your key and security world safely.
trans-unit.target: Therefore it becomes extremely important that you back up your key and security world safely.

trans-unit.source: Contact Thales for guidance and best practices for backing up your key.
trans-unit.target: Contact Thales for guidance and best practices for backing up your key.

trans-unit.source: You are now ready to transfer your tenant key to Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: You are now ready to transfer your tenant key to Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Transfer your tenant key to Azure RMS
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Transfer your tenant key to Azure RMS

trans-unit.source: After you have generated your own key, you must transfer it to Azure RMS before you use it.
trans-unit.target: After you have generated your own key, you must transfer it to Azure RMS before you use it.

trans-unit.source: For the highest level of security, this transfer is a manual process that requires you to fly to the Microsoft office in Redmond, Washington, United States of America.
trans-unit.target: For the highest level of security, this transfer is a manual process that requires you to fly to the Microsoft office in Redmond, Washington, United States of America.

trans-unit.source: To complete this process, follow these 3 steps:
trans-unit.target: To complete this process, follow these 3 steps:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Step 1: Bring your key to Microsoft</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Step 1: Bring your key to Microsoft</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Step 2: Transfer your key to the Window Azure RMS security world</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Step 2: Transfer your key to the Window Azure RMS security world</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Step 3: Closing procedures</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Step 3: Closing procedures</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Bring your key to Microsoft
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Bring your key to Microsoft

trans-unit.source: Contact Microsoft Customer Support Services (CSS) to schedule a key transfer appointment for Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: Contact Microsoft Customer Support Services (CSS) to schedule a key transfer appointment for Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: Bring the following to Microsoft in Redmond:
trans-unit.target: Bring the following to Microsoft in Redmond:

trans-unit.source: A quorum of your Administrative Cards.
trans-unit.target: A quorum of your Administrative Cards.

trans-unit.source: If you followed the previous instructions in <link><linkText>Step 2: Create a security world</linkText><title></title></link>, these are any two of your three cards.
trans-unit.target: If you followed the previous instructions in <link><linkText>Step 2: Create a security world</linkText><title></title></link>, these are any two of your three cards.

trans-unit.source: Personnel authorized to carry your Administrative Cards and pins, typically two (one for each card).
trans-unit.target: Personnel authorized to carry your Administrative Cards and pins, typically two (one for each card).

trans-unit.source: Your Security World file (%NFAST_KMDATA%\local\world) on a USB drive.
trans-unit.target: Your Security World file (%NFAST_KMDATA%\local\world) on a USB drive.

trans-unit.source: Your Tokenized Key File on a USB drive.
trans-unit.target: Your Tokenized Key File on a USB drive.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Transfer your key to the Window Azure RMS security world
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Transfer your key to the Window Azure RMS security world

trans-unit.source: When you arrive at Microsoft to transfer your key, the following happens:
trans-unit.target: When you arrive at Microsoft to transfer your key, the following happens:

trans-unit.source: Microsoft provides you with an offline workstation that has a Thales HSM attached, Thales software installed, and a Azure RMS Security World file pre-loaded into the folder C:\Temp\Destination.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft provides you with an offline workstation that has a Thales HSM attached, Thales software installed, and a Azure RMS Security World file pre-loaded into the folder C:\Temp\Destination.

trans-unit.source: On this workstation, you load your Security World file and Tokenized Key File from your USB drive into the C:\Temp\Source folder.
trans-unit.target: On this workstation, you load your Security World file and Tokenized Key File from your USB drive into the C:\Temp\Source folder.

trans-unit.source: Azure RMS operators securely transfer your key to the Azure RMS security world by using Thales utilities.
trans-unit.target: Azure RMS operators securely transfer your key to the Azure RMS security world by using Thales utilities.

trans-unit.source: This process will look similar to the following, where the last parameter of key-xfer-im in this example is replaced by your Tokenized Key File name:
trans-unit.target: This process will look similar to the following, where the last parameter of key-xfer-im in this example is replaced by your Tokenized Key File name:

trans-unit.source: C:\> mk-reprogram.exe --owner c:\Temp\Destination add c:\Temp\Source
trans-unit.target: C:\> mk-reprogram.exe --owner c:\Temp\Destination add c:\Temp\Source

trans-unit.source: C:\> key-xfer-im.exe c:\Temp\Source c:\Temp\Destination --module c:\Temp\Source\key_caping_machine--801c1a878c925fd9df4d62ba001b94701c039e2fb
trans-unit.target: C:\> key-xfer-im.exe c:\Temp\Source c:\Temp\Destination --module c:\Temp\Source\key_caping_machine--801c1a878c925fd9df4d62ba001b94701c039e2fb

trans-unit.source: Mk-reprogram will ask you and the Azure RMS operators to plug in their respective Administrator cards and pins.
trans-unit.target: Mk-reprogram will ask you and the Azure RMS operators to plug in their respective Administrator cards and pins.

trans-unit.source: These commands output a Tokenized Key File in C:\Temp\Destination that contains your key protected by Azure RMS security world.
trans-unit.target: These commands output a Tokenized Key File in C:\Temp\Destination that contains your key protected by Azure RMS security world.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Closing procedures
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Closing procedures

trans-unit.source: In your presence, Azure RMS operators do the following:
trans-unit.target: In your presence, Azure RMS operators do the following:

trans-unit.source: Run a tool that Microsoft developed in collaboration with Thales that removes two permissions: The permission to recover the key, and the permission to change permissions.
trans-unit.target: Run a tool that Microsoft developed in collaboration with Thales that removes two permissions: The permission to recover the key, and the permission to change permissions.

trans-unit.source: After this is done, this copy of your key is locked to the Azure RMS security world.
trans-unit.target: After this is done, this copy of your key is locked to the Azure RMS security world.

trans-unit.source: Thales HSMs will not allow Azure RMs operators with their Administrator cards to recover the plaintext copy of your key.
trans-unit.target: Thales HSMs will not allow Azure RMs operators with their Administrator cards to recover the plaintext copy of your key.

trans-unit.source: Copy the resulting key file to a USB drive to later upload to the Azure RMS service.
trans-unit.target: Copy the resulting key file to a USB drive to later upload to the Azure RMS service.

trans-unit.source: Factory-reset the HSM, and wipe the workstation clean.
trans-unit.target: Factory-reset the HSM, and wipe the workstation clean.

trans-unit.source: You have now completed all the steps required for bring your own key in person and can return to your organization for the next steps.
trans-unit.target: You have now completed all the steps required for bring your own key in person and can return to your organization for the next steps.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Next steps
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Next steps

trans-unit.source: Start to use your tenant key:
trans-unit.target: Start to use your tenant key:

trans-unit.source: If you haven’t already done so, you must now activate Rights Management so that your organization can start to use RMS.
trans-unit.target: If you haven’t already done so, you must now activate Rights Management so that your organization can start to use RMS.

trans-unit.source: Users immediately start to use your tenant key (managed by Microsoft or managed by you).
trans-unit.target: Users immediately start to use your tenant key (managed by Microsoft or managed by you).

trans-unit.source: For more information about activation, see <link><linkText>Activating Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about activation, see <link><linkText>Activating Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If you had already activated Rights Management and then decided to manage your own tenant key, users gradually transition from the old tenant key to the new tenant key, and this staggered transition can take a few weeks to complete.
trans-unit.target: If you had already activated Rights Management and then decided to manage your own tenant key, users gradually transition from the old tenant key to the new tenant key, and this staggered transition can take a few weeks to complete.

trans-unit.source: Documents and files that were protected with the old tenant key remains accessible to authorized users.
trans-unit.target: Documents and files that were protected with the old tenant key remains accessible to authorized users.

trans-unit.source: Consider enabling usage logging, which logs every transaction that RMS performs.
trans-unit.target: Consider enabling usage logging, which logs every transaction that RMS performs.

trans-unit.source: If you decided to manage your own tenant key, logging includes information about using your tenant key.
trans-unit.target: If you decided to manage your own tenant key, logging includes information about using your tenant key.

trans-unit.source: See the following example of a log file displayed in Excel where the Decrypt and SignDigest Request Types show that the tenant key is being used.
trans-unit.target: See the following example of a log file displayed in Excel where the Decrypt and SignDigest Request Types show that the tenant key is being used.

trans-unit.source: For more information about usage logging, see <link><linkText>Logging and Analyzing Azure Rights Management Usage</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about usage logging, see <link><linkText>Logging and Analyzing Azure Rights Management Usage</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Maintain your tenant key.
trans-unit.target: Maintain your tenant key.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Operations for Your Azure Rights Management Tenant Key</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Operations for Your Azure Rights Management Tenant Key</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.target: See Also
